chargeHist.descr: Possess Narcotics with intent to deliver (Oxycodone)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Lagene C. MCGHEE was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, Oxycodone, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).
  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, Oxycodone, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: incarceration consecutive to any other sentence the defendant may be serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
AODA assessment and follow through counseling.

Pay supervision fees in an amount to be determined by the Department of Corrections.

Submit to random urine screens and pay for same.

Maintain absolute sobriety.

Submit a DNA sample and pay surcharge.

Assessment, treatment, counseling as deemed appropriate by the Department's assessment process.

Use only one doctor and only one pharmacist unless approved otherwise by the agent.

DECISION ON MOTION TO SUPPRESS STATEMENTS
The Court finds the defendant was under arrest and in custody without his Miranda warnings being read when he was questioned about the pills.  Court grants the defendant's motion to suppress the admission that the pills were his.
Regarding the physical evidence seized, the Court finds Deputy Keil had sufficient probable cause to believe that criminal activity was present and, therefore, Deputy Keil had the right to search the vehicle.  The physical evidence seized in this case was appropriately done, therefore, the Court respectfully denies defendant's motion to suppress the physical evidence.
Attorney Hoff is directed to prepare the order.
Scheduling conference set for 06-09-16 at 4:00 p.m.

Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosequendum and Order to Sheriff to transport defendant for Initial Appearance on 04-27-15 at 2:30 p.m. and Preliminary Hearing on 04-28-15 at 10:15 a.m.   
Copy filed.
Philip Hoff, through Public Defender.
RE:  Possess Oxycodone with intent to deliver, on 03-19-15.

Defendant in custody.  The State informs the Court that the defendant will be charged with the crimes of possess schedule II narcotic with intent to deliver, possess schedule II non-narcotic with intent to deliver.  The matters are continued for initial appearance on 04-06-15 at 2:30 p.m. Bail is set at $4,000.00 recognizance bond with the conditions that he report to the Manitowoc County Sheriff's Department for fingerprints, photographs and other identifying information within 24 hours of release and not to possess any controlled substances without a valid prescription.   Bail furnished and defendant is remanded into custody on a probation hold.
Probable Cause Statement and Judicial Determination.
